column1: HTTP cookie;"An HTTP cookie (also called web cookie
column2: Internet cookie
column3: browser cookie
column4: or simply cookie) is a small piece of data sent from a website and stored on the user's computer by the user's web browser while the user is browsing. Cookies were designed to be a reliable mechanism for websites to remember stateful information (such as items added in the shopping cart in an online store) or to record the user's browsing activity (including clicking particular buttons
column5: logging in
column6: or recording which pages were visited in the past). They can also be used to remember arbitrary pieces of information that the user previously entered into form fields such as names
column7: addresses
column8: passwords
column9: and credit card numbers.

column1: Cookies perform essential functions in the modern web. Perhaps most importantly
column2: authentication cookies are the most common method used by web servers to know whether the user is logged in or not
column3: and which account they are logged in with. Without such a mechanism
column4: the site would not know whether to send a page containing sensitive information
column5: or require the user to authenticate themselves by logging in. The security of an authentication cookie generally depends on the security of the issuing website and the user's web browser
column6: and on whether the cookie data is encrypted. Security vulnerabilities may allow a cookie's data to be read by a hacker
column7: used to gain access to user data
column8: or used to gain access (with the user's credentials) to the website to which the cookie belongs (see cross-site scripting and cross-site request forgery for examples).Tracking cookies
column9: and especially third-party tracking cookies
column10: are commonly used as ways to compile long-term records of individuals' browsing histories – a potential privacy concern that prompted European and U.S. lawmakers to take action in 2011. European law requires that all websites targeting European Union member states gain ""informed consent"" from users before storing non-essential cookies on their device.

column1: Google Project Zero researcher Jann Horn describes ways cookies can be read by intermediaries
column2: like Wi-Fi hotspot providers. He recommends to use the browser in incognito mode in such circumstances.

column1: The term ""cookie"" was coined by web browser programmer Lou Montulli. It was derived from the term ""magic cookie""
column2: which is a packet of data a program receives and sends back unchanged
column3: used by Unix programmers.

column1: Magic cookies were already used in computing when computer programmer Lou Montulli had the idea of using them in web communications in June 1994. At the time
column2: he was an employee of Netscape Communications
column3: which was developing an e-commerce application for MCI. Vint Cerf and John Klensin represented MCI in technical discussions with Netscape Communications. MCI did not want its servers to have to retain partial transaction states
column4: which led them to ask Netscape to find a way to store that state in each user's computer instead. Cookies provided a solution to the problem of reliably implementing a virtual shopping cart.Together with John Giannandrea
column5: Montulli wrote the initial Netscape cookie specification the same year. Version 0.9beta of Mosaic Netscape
column6: released on October 13
column8: supported cookies. The first use of cookies (out of the labs) was checking whether visitors to the Netscape website had already visited the site. Montulli applied for a patent for the cookie technology in 1995
column9: and US 5774670  was granted in 1998. Support for cookies was integrated in Internet Explorer in version 2
column10: released in October 1995.The introduction of cookies was not widely known to the public at the time. In particular
column11: cookies were accepted by default
column12: and users were not notified of their presence. The general public learned about cookies after the Financial Times published an article about them on February 12
column13: 1996. In the same year
column14: cookies received a lot of media attention
column15: especially because of potential privacy implications. Cookies were discussed in two U.S. Federal Trade Commission hearings in 1996 and 1997.

column1: The development of the formal cookie specifications was already ongoing. In particular
column2: the first discussions about a formal specification started in April 1995 on the www-talk mailing list. A special working group within the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) was formed. Two alternative proposals for introducing state in HTTP transactions had been proposed by Brian Behlendorf and David Kristol respectively. But the group
column3: headed by Kristol himself and Lou Montulli
column4: soon decided to use the Netscape specification as a starting point. In February 1996
column5: the working group identified third-party cookies as a considerable privacy threat. The specification produced by the group was eventually published as RFC 2109 in February 1997. It specifies that third-party cookies were either not allowed at all
column6: or at least not enabled by default.

column2: advertising companies were already using third-party cookies. The recommendation about third-party cookies of RFC 2109 was not followed by Netscape and Internet Explorer. RFC 2109 was superseded by RFC 2965 in October 2000.
which informally came to be called ""RFC 2965-style cookies"" as opposed to the original Set-Cookie header which was called ""Netscape-style cookies"". Set-Cookie2 was seldom used however
column3: and was deprecated in RFC 6265 in April 2011 which was written as a definitive specification for cookies as used in the real world.

column2: also known as an in-memory cookie
column3: transient cookie or non-persistent cookie
column4: exists only in temporary memory while the user navigates the website.

column1: Web browsers normally delete session cookies when the user closes the browser. Unlike other cookies
column2: session cookies do not have an expiration date assigned to them
column3: which is how the browser knows to treat them as session cookies.

column1: Instead of expiring when the web browser is closed as session cookies do
column2: a persistent cookie expires at a specific date or after a specific length of time. This means that
column3: for the cookie's entire lifespan (which can be as long or as short as its creators want)
column4: its information will be transmitted to the server every time the user visits the website that it belongs to
column5: or every time the user views a resource belonging to that website from another website (such as an advertisement).

column2: persistent cookies are sometimes referred to as tracking cookies because they can be used by advertisers to record information about a user's web browsing habits over an extended period of time. However
column3: they are also used for ""legitimate"" reasons (such as keeping users logged into their accounts on websites
column4: to avoid re-entering login credentials at every visit).

column1: A secure cookie can only be transmitted over an encrypted connection (i.e. HTTPS). They cannot be transmitted over unencrypted connections (i.e. HTTP). This makes the cookie less likely to be exposed to cookie theft via eavesdropping. A cookie is made secure by adding the Secure flag to the cookie.
An http-only cookie cannot be accessed by client-side APIs
column2: such as JavaScript. This restriction eliminates the threat of cookie theft via cross-site scripting (XSS). However
column3: the cookie remains vulnerable to cross-site tracing (XST) and cross-site request forgery (XSRF) attacks. A cookie is given this characteristic by adding the HttpOnly flag to the cookie.

column1: In 2016 Google Chrome version 51 introduced a new kind of cookie
column2: the same-site cookie
column3: which can only be sent in requests originating from the same origin as the target domain. This restriction mitigates attacks such as cross-site request forgery (XSRF). A cookie is given this characteristic by setting the SameSite flag to Strict or Lax.

column2: a cookie's domain attribute will match the domain that is shown in the web browser's address bar. This is called a first-party cookie. A third-party cookie
column3: however
column4: belongs to a domain different from the one shown in the address bar. This sort of cookie typically appears when web pages feature content from external websites
column5: such as banner advertisements. This opens up the potential for tracking the user's browsing history and is often used by advertisers in an effort to serve relevant advertisements to each user.

column2: suppose a user visits www.example.org. This website contains an advertisement from ad.foxytracking.com
column3: which
column4: when downloaded
column5: sets a cookie belonging to the advertisement's domain (ad.foxytracking.com). Then
column6: the user visits another website
column7: www.foo.com
column8: which also contains an advertisement from ad.foxytracking.com and sets a cookie belonging to that domain (ad.foxytracking.com). Eventually
column9: both of these cookies will be sent to the advertiser when loading their advertisements or visiting their website. The advertiser can then use these cookies to build up a browsing history of the user across all the websites that have ads from this advertiser.

column3: a single website was setting 10 cookies
column4: with a maximum number of cookies (first- and third-party) reaching over 800.Most modern web browsers contain privacy settings that can block third-party cookies.

column1: A supercookie is a cookie with an origin of a top-level domain (such as .com) or a public suffix (such as .co.uk). Ordinary cookies
column2: by contrast
column3: have an origin of a specific domain name
column4: such as example.com.

column1: Supercookies can be a potential security concern and are therefore often blocked by web browsers. If unblocked by the browser
column2: an attacker in control of a malicious website could set a supercookie and potentially disrupt or impersonate legitimate user requests to another website that shares the same top-level domain or public suffix as the malicious website. For example
column3: a supercookie with an origin of .com
column4: could maliciously affect a request made to example.com
column5: even if the cookie did not originate from example.com. This can be used to fake logins or change user information.

column1: The Public Suffix List helps to mitigate the risk that supercookies pose. The Public Suffix List is a cross-vendor initiative that aims to provide an accurate and up-to-date list of domain name suffixes. Older versions of browsers may not have an up-to-date list
column2: and will therefore be vulnerable to supercookies from certain domains.

column1: The term ""supercookie"" is sometimes used for tracking technologies that do not rely on HTTP cookies. Two such ""supercookie"" mechanisms were found on Microsoft websites in August 2011: cookie syncing that respawned MUID (machine unique identifier) cookies
column2: and ETag cookies. Due to media attention
column3: Microsoft later disabled this code.

column1: A zombie cookie is a cookie that is automatically recreated after being deleted. This is accomplished by storing the cookie's content in multiple locations
column2: such as Flash Local shared object
column3: HTML5 Web storage
column4: and other client-side and even server-side locations. When the cookie's absence is detected
column5: the cookie is recreated using the data stored in these locations.

column1: A cookie consists of the following components:
Zero or more attributes (name/value pairs). Attributes store information such as the cookie's expiration
column2: domain
column3: and flags (such as Secure and HttpOnly).

column1: Cookies were originally introduced to provide a way for users to record items they want to purchase as they navigate throughout a website (a virtual ""shopping cart"" or ""shopping basket""). Today
column2: however
column3: the contents of a user's shopping cart are usually stored in a database on the server
column4: rather than in a cookie on the client. To keep track of which user is assigned to which shopping cart
column5: the server sends a cookie to the client that contains a unique session identifier (typically
column6: a long string of random letters and numbers). Because cookies are sent to the server with every request the client makes
column7: that session identifier will be sent back to the server every time the user visits a new page on the website
column8: which lets the server know which shopping cart to display to the user.

column1: Another popular use of cookies is for logging into websites. When the user visits a website's login page
column2: the web server typically sends the client a cookie containing a unique session identifier. When the user successfully logs in
column3: the server remembers that that particular session identifier has been authenticated and grants the user access to its services.

column1: Because session cookies only contain a unique session identifier
column2: this makes the amount of personal information that a website can save about each user virtually limitless—the website is not limited to restrictions concerning how large a cookie can be. Session cookies also help to improve page load times
column3: since the amount of information in a session cookie is small and requires little bandwidth.

column1: Cookies can be used to remember information about the user in order to show relevant content to that user over time. For example
column2: a web server might send a cookie containing the username that was last used to log into a website
column3: so that it may be filled in automatically the next time the user logs in.

column1: Many websites use cookies for personalization based on the user's preferences. Users select their preferences by entering them in a web form and submitting the form to the server. The server encodes the preferences in a cookie and sends the cookie back to the browser. This way
column2: every time the user accesses a page on the website
column3: the server can personalize the page according to the user's preferences. For example
column4: the Google search engine once used cookies to allow users (even non-registered ones) to decide how many search results per page they wanted to see.

column2: DuckDuckGo uses cookies to allow users to set the viewing preferences like colors of the web page.

column1: Tracking cookies are used to track users' web browsing habits. This can also be done to some extent by using the IP address of the computer requesting the page or the referer field of the HTTP request header
column2: but cookies allow for greater precision. This can be demonstrated as follows:

column1: If the user requests a page of the site
column2: but the request contains no cookie
column3: the server presumes that this is the first page visited by the user. So the server creates a unique identifier (typically a string of random letters and numbers) and sends it as a cookie back to the browser together with the requested page.

column2: the cookie will automatically be sent by the browser to the server every time a new page from the site is requested. The server not only sends the page as usual but also stores the URL of the requested page
column3: the date/time of the request
column4: and the cookie in a log file.By analyzing this log file
column5: it is then possible to find out which pages the user has visited
column6: in what sequence
column7: and for how long.

column1: Corporations exploit users' web habits by tracking cookies to collect information about buying habits. The Wall Street Journal found that America's top fifty websites installed an average of sixty-four pieces of tracking technology onto computers
column2: resulting in a total of 3
column3: 180 tracking files. The data can then be collected and sold to bidding corporations.

column1: Cookies are arbitrary pieces of data
column2: usually chosen and first sent by the web server
column3: and stored on the client computer by the web browser. The browser then sends them back to the server with every request
column4: introducing states (memory of previous events) into otherwise stateless HTTP transactions. Without cookies
column5: each retrieval of a web page or component of a web page would be an isolated event
column6: largely unrelated to all other page views made by the user on the website. Although cookies are usually set by the web server
column7: they can also be set by the client using a scripting language such as JavaScript (unless the cookie's HttpOnly flag is set
column8: in which case the cookie cannot be modified by scripting languages).

column1: The value of a cookie can be modified by the server by including a Set-Cookie header in response to a page request. The browser then replaces the old value with the new value.
The value of a cookie may consist of any printable ASCII character (! through ~
column2: Unicode \u0021 through \u007E) excluding
column3: and ; and whitespace characters. The name of a cookie excludes the same characters
column4: as well as =
column5: since that is the delimiter between the name and value. The cookie standard RFC 2965 is more restrictive but not implemented by browsers.

column2: the object document.cookie is used for this purpose. For example
column3: the instruction document.cookie = ""temperature=20"" creates a cookie of name ""temperature"" and value ""20"".

column1: In addition to a name and value
column2: cookies can also have one or more attributes. Browsers do not include cookie attributes in requests to the server—they only send the cookie's name and value. Cookie attributes are used by browsers to determine when to delete a cookie
column3: block a cookie or whether to send a cookie to the server.

column1: The Domain and Path attributes define the scope of the cookie. They essentially tell the browser what website the cookie belongs to. For obvious security reasons
column2: cookies can only be set on the current resource's top domain and its sub domains
column3: and not for another domain and its sub domains. For example
column4: the website example.org cannot set a cookie that has a domain of foo.com because this would allow the example.org website to control the cookies of foo.com.

column1: If a cookie's Domain and Path attributes are not specified by the server
column2: they default to the domain and path of the resource that was requested. However
column3: in most browsers there is a difference between a cookie set from foo.com without a domain
column4: and a cookie set with the foo.com domain. In the former case
column5: the cookie will only be sent for requests to foo.com
column6: also known as a host-only cookie. In the latter case
column7: all sub domains are also included (for example
column8: docs.foo.com). A notable exception to this general rule is Edge prior to Windows 10 RS3 and Internet Explorer prior to IE 11 and Windows 10 RS4 (April 2018)
column9: which always send cookies to sub domains regardless of whether the cookie was set with or without a domain.Below is an example of some Set-Cookie HTTP response headers that are sent from a website after a user logged in. column4: and has a Path attribute set to /accounts. This tells the browser to use the cookie only when requesting pages contained in docs.foo.com/accounts (the domain is derived from the request domain). The other two cookies

The Secure and HttpOnly attributes do not have associated values. Rather
column2: the presence of just their attribute names indicates that their behaviors should be enabled.

column1: The Secure attribute is meant to keep cookie communication limited to encrypted transmission
column2: directing browsers to use cookies only via secure/encrypted connections. However
column3: if a web server sets a cookie with a secure attribute from a non-secure connection
column4: the cookie can still be intercepted when it is sent to the user by man-in-the-middle attacks. Therefore
column5: for maximum security
column6: cookies with the Secure attribute should only be set over a secure connection.

column1: The HttpOnly attribute directs browsers not to expose cookies through channels other than HTTP (and HTTPS) requests. This means that the cookie cannot be accessed via client-side scripting languages (notably JavaScript)
column2: and therefore cannot be stolen easily via cross-site scripting (a pervasive attack technique).

column1: Cookies have some important implications on the privacy and anonymity of web users. While cookies are sent only to the server setting them or a server in the same Internet domain
column2: a web page may contain images or other components stored on servers in other domains. Cookies that are set during retrieval of these components are called third-party cookies. The older standards for cookies
column3: RFC 2109 and RFC 2965
column4: specify that browsers should protect user privacy and not allow sharing of cookies between servers by default. However
column5: the newer standard
column6: RFC 6265
column7: explicitly allows user agents to implement whichever third-party cookie policy they wish. Most browsers
column8: such as Mozilla Firefox
column9: Internet Explorer
column10: Opera
column11: and Google Chrome
column12: do allow third-party cookies by default
column13: as long as the third-party website has Compact Privacy Policy published. Newer versions of Safari block third-party cookies
column14: and this is planned for Mozilla Firefox as well (initially planned for version 22 but postponed indefinitely).

column1: Advertising companies use third-party cookies to track a user across multiple sites. In particular
column2: an advertising company can track a user across all pages where it has placed advertising images or web bugs. Knowledge of the pages visited by a user allows the advertising company to target advertisements to the user's presumed preferences.

column1: Website operators who do not disclose third-party cookie use to consumers run the risk of harming consumer trust if cookie use is discovered. Having clear disclosure (such as in a privacy policy) tends to eliminate any negative effects of such cookie discovery.The possibility of building a profile of users is a privacy threat

column1: An HTTP session is a sequence of network request-response transactions. An HTTP client initiates a request by establishing a Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) connection to a particular port on a server (typically port 80
column2: occasionally port 8080; see List of TCP and UDP port numbers). An HTTP server listening on that port waits for a client's request message. Upon receiving the request
column3: the server sends back a status line
column4: such as ""HTTP/1.1 200 OK""
column5: and a message of its own. The body of this message is typically the requested resource
column6: although an error message or other information may also be returned.

column2: the connection is closed after a single request/response pair. In HTTP/1.1 a keep-alive-mechanism was introduced
column3: where a connection could be reused for more than one request. Such persistent connections reduce request latency perceptibly
column4: because the client does not need to re-negotiate the TCP 3-Way-Handshake connection after the first request has been sent. Another positive side effect is that
column5: in general
column6: the connection becomes faster with time due to TCP's slow-start-mechanism.

column1: Global warming;"Global warming is long-term rise in the average temperature of the Earth's climate system
column2: an aspect of current climate change shown by temperature measurements and by multiple effects of the warming. The term commonly refers to the mainly human-caused increase in global surface temperatures and its projected continuation. In this context
column3: the terms global warming and climate change are often used interchangeably
column4: but climate change includes both global warming and its effects
column5: such as changes in precipitation and impacts that differ by region. There were prehistoric periods of global warming
column6: but observed changes since the mid-20th century have been much greater than those seen in previous records covering decades to thousands of years.In 2013
column7: the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Fifth Assessment Report concluded
column8: ""It is extremely likely that human influence has been the dominant cause of the observed warming since the mid-20th century."" The largest human influence has been the emission of greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide
column9: methane
column10: and nitrous oxide. Climate model projections summarized in the report indicated that during the 21st century the global surface temperature is likely to rise a further 0.3 to 1.7 °C (0.5 to 3.1 °F) in a moderate scenario
column11: or as much as 2.6 to 4.8 °C (4.7 to 8.6 °F) in an extreme scenario
column12: depending on the rate of future greenhouse gas emissions and on climate feedback effects. These findings have been recognized by the national science academies of the major industrialized nations and are not disputed by any scientific body of national or international standing.The effects of global warming include rising sea levels
column13: regional changes in precipitation
column14: more frequent extreme weather events such as heat waves
column15: and expansion of deserts. Surface temperature increases are greatest in the Arctic
column16: which has contributed to the retreat of glaciers
column17: permafrost
column18: and sea ice. Overall
column19: higher temperatures bring more rain and snowfall
column20: but for some regions droughts and wildfires increase instead. Climate change threatens to diminish crop yields
column21: harming food security
column22: and rising sea levels may flood coastal infrastructure and force the abandonment of many coastal cities. Environmental impacts include the extinction or relocation of many species as their ecosystems change
column23: most immediately the environments of coral reefs
column24: mountains
column25: and the Arctic. Because the climate system has a large ""inertia"" and greenhouse gases persist in the atmosphere
column26: climatic changes and their effects will intensify for many centuries even if further greenhouse gas emissions stop.Globally
column27: a majority of people consider global warming a serious or very serious issue. Possible societal responses to global warming include mitigation by emissions reduction
column28: adaptation to its effects
column29: and possible future climate engineering. Every country in the world is a party to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)
column30: whose ultimate objective is to prevent dangerous anthropogenic climate change. Although the parties to the UNFCCC have agreed that deep cuts in emissions are required and that global warming should be limited to well below 2 °C (3.6 °F) (with efforts made to limit warming to 1.5 °C (2.7 °F))
column31: the Earth's average surface temperature has already increased by about half this threshold. Some scientists call into question the feasibility of the 2 °C (3.6 °F) temperature target
column32: and some question the feasibility
column33: in higher emissions scenarios
column34: of climate adaptation.

column1: Climate proxy records show that natural variations offset the early effects of the Industrial Revolution
column2: so there was little net warming between the 18th century and the mid-19th century
column3: when thermometer records began to provide global coverage. The IPCC has adopted the baseline reference period 1850–1900 as an approximation of pre-industrial global mean surface temperature.Multiple independently produced instrumental datasets confirm that the 2009–2018 decade was 0.93 ± 0.07 °C warmer than the pre-industrial baseline (1850–1900). Currently
column4: surface temperatures are rising by about 0.2 °C per decade. Since 1950
column5: the number of cold days and nights have decreased
column6: and the number of warm days and night have increased. Historical patterns of warming and cooling
column7: like the Medieval Climate Anomaly and the Little Ice Age
column8: were not as synchronous as current warming
column9: but may have reached temperatures as high as those of the late-20th century in a limited set of regions.Although the most common measure of global warming is the increase in the near-surface atmospheric temperature
column10: over 90% of the additional energy stored in the climate system over the last 50 years has warmed ocean water. The remainder of the additional energy has melted ice and warmed the continents and the atmosphere.The warming evident in the instrumental temperature record is consistent with a wide range of observations
column11: documented by many independent scientific groups; for example
column12: in most continental regions the frequency and intensity of heavy precipitation has increased. Further examples include sea level rise
column13: widespread melting of snow and land ice
column14: increased heat content of the oceans
column15: increased humidity
column16: and the earlier timing of spring events
column17: such as the flowering of plants.

column1: Global warming refers to global averages

column3: global average land temperatures have increased about twice as fast as global average ocean temperatures. This is due to the larger heat capacity of oceans and because oceans lose more heat by evaporation. Arctic temperatures have increased and are predicted to continue to increase during this century at over twice the rate of the rest of the world. As the temperature difference between the Arctic and the equator decreases

column1: Because the climate system has large thermal inertia
column2: it can take centuries for the climate to fully adjust. While record-breaking years attract considerable public interest
column3: individual years are less significant than the overall trend. Global surface temperature is subject to short-term fluctuations that overlie long-term trends
column4: and can temporarily mask or magnify them. An example of such an episode is the slower rate of surface temperature increase from 1998 to 2012
column5: which was dubbed the global warming hiatus. Throughout this period ocean heat storage continued to progress steadily upwards
column6: and in subsequent years surface temperatures have spiked upwards. The slower pace of warming can be attributed to a combination of natural fluctuations

column1: == Physical drivers of recent climate change ==

column2: the climate system experiences various cycles which can last for years (such as the El Niño–Southern Oscillation) to decades or centuries. Other changes are caused by external forcings. These forcings are ""external"" to the climate system
column3: but not always external to the Earth. Examples of external forcings include changes in the composition of the atmosphere (e.g.
column4: increased concentrations of greenhouse gases)
column5: solar luminosity
column6: volcanic eruptions
column7: and variations in the Earth's orbit around the Sun.Attributing detected temperature changes and extreme events to human-caused increases in greenhouse gases requires scientists to rule out known internal climate variability and natural external forcings. Therefore
column8: a key approach is to use physically or statistically based computer modelling of the climate system to determine unique fingerprints for all potential causes. By comparing these fingerprints with observed patterns and evolution of climate change
column9: and the observed evolution of the forcings
column10: the causes of the observed changes can be determined. Scientists have determined that the major factors in the current climate change are greenhouse gases
column11: land use changes
column12: and aerosols and soot.

column1: Greenhouse gases trap heat radiating from the Earth to space. This heat
column2: in the form of infrared radiation
column3: gets absorbed and emitted by these gases in the atmosphere
column4: thus warming the lower atmosphere and the surface. Before the Industrial Revolution
column5: naturally occurring amounts of greenhouse gases caused the air near the surface to be warmer by about 33 °C (59 °F) than it would be in their absence. Without the Earth's atmosphere
column6: the Earth's average temperature would be well below the freezing temperature of water. The major greenhouse gases are water vapour
column7: which causes about 36–70% of the greenhouse effect; carbon dioxide (CO2)
column8: which causes 9–26%; methane (CH4)
column9: which causes 4–9%; and ozone (O3)
column10: which causes 3–7%.Human activity since the Industrial Revolution has increased the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere
column11: leading to increased radiative forcing from CO2
column12: methane
column13: tropospheric ozone
column14: CFCs
column15: and nitrous oxide. As of 2011
column16: the concentrations of CO2 and methane had increased by about 40% and 150%
column17: respectively
column18: since pre-industrial times. In 2013
column19: CO2 readings taken at the world's primary benchmark site in Mauna Loa surpassing 400 ppm for the first time. These levels are much higher than at any time during the last 800
column20: 000 years
column21: the period for which reliable data have been collected from ice cores. Less direct geological evidence indicates that CO2 values have not been this high for millions of years.Global anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions in 2010 were equivalent to 49 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide (using the most recent global warming potentials over 100 years from the AR5 report). Of these emissions
column22: 65% was carbon dioxide from fossil fuel burning and industry
column23: 11% was carbon dioxide from land use change
column24: which is primarily due to deforestation
column25: 16% was from methane
column26: 6.2% was from nitrous oxide
column27: and 2.0% was from fluorinated gases. Using life-cycle assessment to estimate emissions relating to final consumption
column28: the dominant sources of 2010 emissions were: food (26–30% of emissions); washing
column29: heating
column30: and lighting (26%); personal transport and freight (20%); and building construction (15%).

column1: Changing the type of vegetation in a region impacts the local temperature by changing how much sunlight gets reflected back into space
column2: called albedo
column3: and how much heat is lost by evaporation. For instance
column4: the change from a dark forest to grassland makes the surface lighter
column5: and causes it to reflect more sunlight. Humans change the land surface mainly to create more agricultural land. Since the pre-industrial era

column7: which has a cooling effect on the planet. Other processes linked to land use change however have had the opposite effect

column1: Solid and liquid particles known as aerosols – from volcanoes
column2: plankton
column3: and human-made pollutants – reflect incoming sunlight
column4: cooling the climate. From 1961 to 1990

column18: heating the atmosphere and cooling the surface. In areas with high soot production
column19: such as rural India

column21: including black carbon

column1: === Minor forcings: the Sun and short-lived greenhouse gases ===
As the Sun is the Earth's primary energy source
column2: changes in incoming sunlight directly affect the climate system. Solar irradiance has been measured directly by satellites
column3: and indirect measurements are available beginning in the early 1600s. There has been no upward trend in the amount of the Sun's energy reaching the Earth
column4: so it cannot be responsible for the current warming. Physical climate models are also unable to reproduce the rapid warming observed in recent decades when taking into account only variations in solar output and volcanic activity. Another line of evidence for the warming not being due to the Sun is how temperature changes differ at different levels in the Earth's atmosphere. According to basic physical principles
column5: the greenhouse effect produces warming of the lower atmosphere (the troposphere)
column6: but cooling of the upper atmosphere (the stratosphere). If solar variations were responsible for the observed warming
column7: warming of both the troposphere and the stratosphere would be expected

column9: the troposphere
column10: is itself a greenhouse gas. Furthermore
column11: it is highly reactive and interacts with other greenhouse gases and aerosols.

column1: The response of the climate system to an initial forcing is increased by positive feedbacks and reduced by negative feedbacks. The main negative feedback to global temperature change is radiative cooling to space as infrared radiation
column2: which increases strongly with increasing temperature. The main positive feedbacks are the water vapour feedback
column3: the ice–albedo feedback
column4: and probably the net effect of clouds. Uncertainty over feedbacks is the major reason why different climate models project different magnitudes of warming for a given amount of emissions.As air gets warmer
column5: it can hold more moisture. After an initial warming due to emissions of greenhouse gases
column6: the atmosphere will hold more water. As water is a potent greenhouse gas
column7: this further heats the climate: the water vapour feedback. The reduction of snow cover and sea ice in the Arctic reduces the albedo (reflectivity) of the Earth's surface. More of the sun's energy is now absorbed in these regions
column8: contributing to Arctic amplification
column9: which has caused Arctic temperatures to increase at almost twice the rate of the rest of the world. Arctic amplification also causes methane to be released as permafrost melts
column10: which is expected to surpass land use changes as the second strongest anthropogenic source of greenhouse gases by the end of the century.Cloud cover may change in the future. If cloud cover increases
column11: more sunlight will be reflected back into space
column12: cooling the planet. Simultaneously
column13: the clouds enhance the greenhouse effect
column14: warming the planet. The opposite is true if cloud cover decreases. It depends on the cloud type and location which process is more important. Overall
column15: the net feedback over the industrial era has probably been positive. An analysis of satellite data between 1983 and 2009 reveals that cloud tops are reaching higher into the atmosphere and that cloudy storm tracks are shifting toward Earth's poles
column16: suggesting clouds will be a positive feedback in the future.Carbon dioxide stimulates plant growth so the carbon cycle has been a negative feedback so far: roughly half of each year's CO2 emissions have been absorbed by plants on land and in oceans
column17: with an estimated 30% increase in plant growth from 2000 to 2017. The limits and reversal point for this feedback are an area of uncertainty. As more CO2 and heat are absorbed by the ocean it is acidifying and ocean circulation can change
column18: changing the rate at which the ocean can absorb atmospheric carbon. On land
column19: greater plant growth will be constrained by nitrogen levels and can be reversed by plant heat stress
column20: desertification
column21: and the release of carbon from soil as the ground warms.A concern is that positive feedbacks will lead to a tipping point
column22: where global temperatures transition to a hothouse climate state even if greenhouse gas emissions are reduced or eliminated. A 2018 study tried to identify such a planetary threshold for self-reinforcing feedbacks and found that even a 2 °C (3.6 °F) increase in temperature over pre-industrial levels may be enough to trigger such a hothouse Earth scenario.

column1: A climate model is a representation of the physical
column2: chemical
column3: and biological processes that affect the climate system. Computer models are run on supercomputers to reproduce and predict the circulation of the oceans
column4: the annual cycle of the seasons
column5: and the flows of carbon between the land surface and the atmosphere. There are more than two dozen scientific institutions that develop climate models. Model forecasts vary due to different greenhouse gas inputs and different assumptions about the impact of different feedbacks on climate sensitivity.

column1: A subset of climate models add societal factors to a simple physical climate model. These models simulate how population
column2: economic growth
column3: and energy use affect – and interact with – the physical climate. With this information
column4: scientists can produce scenarios of how greenhouse gas emissions may vary in the future. Scientists can then run these scenarios through physical climate models to generate climate change projections.Climate models include different external forcings for their models. For different greenhouse gas inputs four RCPs (Representative Concentration Pathways) are used: ""a stringent mitigation scenario (RCP2.6)
column5: two intermediate scenarios (RCP4.5 and RCP6.0) and one scenario with very high GHG [greenhouse gas] emissions (RCP8.5)"". Models also include changes in the Earth's orbit
column6: historical changes in the Sun's activity
column7: and volcanic forcing. RCPs only look at concentrations of greenhouse gases
column8: factoring out uncertainty as to whether the carbon cycle will continue to remove about half of the carbon dioxide from the atmosphere each year.The physical realism of models is tested by examining their ability to simulate contemporary or past climates. Past models have underestimated the rate of Arctic shrinkage and underestimated the rate of precipitation increase. Sea level rise since 1990 was underestimated in older models
column9: but now agrees well with observations. The 2017 United States-published National Climate Assessment notes that ""climate models may still be underestimating or missing relevant feedback processes"".

column1: Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Action;"Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Action (NAMA) refers to a set of policies and actions that countries undertake as part of a commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The term recognizes that different countries may take different nationally appropriate action on the basis of equity and in accordance with common but differentiated responsibilities and respective capabilities. It also emphasizes financial assistance from developed countries to developing countries to reduce emissions.
NAMA was first used in the Bali Action Plan as part of the Bali Road Map agreed at the United Nations Climate Change Conference in Bali in December 2007
column2: and also formed part of the Copenhagen Accord issued following the United Nations Climate Change Conference in Copenhagen (COP 15) in December 2009.

The isolation rate can be increased by incubating the cultures under anaerobic conditions and using selective growth media. column1: Hepatitis B;"Hepatitis B is an infectious disease caused by the hepatitis B virus (HBV) that affects the liver. It can cause both acute and chronic infections. Many people have no symptoms during the initial infection. Some develop a rapid onset of sickness with vomiting
column2: yellowish skin
column3: tiredness
column4: dark urine and abdominal pain. Often these symptoms last a few weeks and rarely does the initial infection result in death. It may take 30 to 180 days for symptoms to begin. In those who get infected around the time of birth 90% develop chronic hepatitis B while less than 10% of those infected after the age of five do. Most of those with chronic disease have no symptoms; however
column5: cirrhosis and liver cancer may eventually develop. Cirrhosis or liver cancer occur in about 25% of those with chronic disease.The virus is transmitted by exposure to infectious blood or body fluids. Infection around the time of birth or from contact with other people's blood during childhood is the most frequent method by which hepatitis B is acquired in areas where the disease is common. In areas where the disease is rare
column6: intravenous drug use and sexual intercourse are the most frequent routes of infection. Other risk factors include working in healthcare
column7: blood transfusions
column8: dialysis
column9: living with an infected person
column10: travel in countries where the infection rate is high
column11: and living in an institution. Tattooing and acupuncture led to a significant number of cases in the 1980s; however
column12: this has become less common with improved sterility. The hepatitis B viruses cannot be spread by holding hands
column13: sharing eating utensils
column14: kissing
column15: hugging
column16: coughing
column17: sneezing
column18: or breastfeeding. The infection can be diagnosed 30 to 60 days after exposure. The diagnosis is usually confirmed by testing the blood for parts of the virus and for antibodies against the virus. It is one of five main hepatitis viruses: A
column19: B
column20: C
column21: D
column22: and E.The infection has been preventable by vaccination since 1982. Vaccination is recommended by the World Health Organization in the first day of life if possible. Two or three more doses are required at a later time for full effect. This vaccine works about 95% of the time. About 180 countries gave the vaccine as part of national programs as of 2006. It is also recommended that all blood be tested for hepatitis B before transfusion
column23: and that condoms be used to prevent infection. During an initial infection
column24: care is based on the symptoms that a person has. In those who develop chronic disease
column25: antiviral medication such as tenofovir or interferon may be useful; however
column26: these drugs are expensive. Liver transplantation is sometimes used for cirrhosis.About a third of the world population has been infected at one point in their lives
column27: including 343 million who have chronic infections. Another 129 million new infections occurred in 2013. Over 750
column28: 000 people die of hepatitis B each year. About 300
column29: 000 of these are due to liver cancer. The disease is now only  common in East Asia and sub-Saharan Africa where between 5 and 10% of adults are chronically infected. Rates in Europe and North America are less than 1%. It was originally known as ""serum hepatitis"". Research is looking to create foods that contain HBV vaccine. The disease may affect other great apes as well.

The infection may be entirely asymptomatic and may go unrecognized.Chronic infection with hepatitis B virus either may be asymptomatic or may be associated with a chronic inflammation of the liver (chronic hepatitis)

column1: Transmission of hepatitis B virus results from exposure to infectious blood or body fluids containing blood. It is 50 to 100 times more infectious than human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). Possible forms of transmission include sexual contact

column1: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a member of the hepadnavirus family. The virus particle (virion) consists of an outer lipid envelope and an icosahedral nucleocapsid core composed of protein. These virions are 30–42 nm in diameter. The nucleocapsid encloses the viral DNA and a DNA polymerase that has reverse transcriptase activity. The outer envelope contains embedded proteins that are involved in viral binding of
column2: and entry into
column3: susceptible cells. The virus is one of the smallest enveloped animal viruses.  The 42 nm virions
column4: which are capable of infecting liver cells known as hepatocytes
column5: are referred to as ""Dane particles"". In addition to the Dane particles
column6: filamentous and spherical bodies lacking a core can be found in the serum of infected individuals.   These particles are not infectious and are composed of the lipid and protein that forms part of the surface of the virion
column7: which is called the surface antigens (HBsAg)
column8: and is produced in excess during the life cycle of the virus.

column1: The genome of HBV is made of circular DNA
column2: but it is unusual because the DNA is not fully double-stranded. One end of the full length strand is linked to the viral DNA polymerase. The genome is 3020–3320 nucleotides long (for the full-length strand) and 1700–2800 nucleotides long (for the short length-strand). The negative-sense (non-coding) is complementary to the viral mRNA. The viral DNA is found in the nucleus soon after infection of the cell. The partially double-stranded DNA is rendered fully double-stranded by completion of the (+) sense strand and removal of a protein molecule from the (−) sense strand and a short sequence of RNA from the (+) sense strand. Non-coding bases are removed from the ends of the (−) sense strand and the ends are rejoined. There are four known genes encoded by the genome
column3: called C
column4: X
column5: P
column6: and S. The core protein is coded for by gene C (HBcAg)
column7: and its start codon is preceded by an upstream in-frame AUG start codon from which the pre-core protein is produced. HBeAg is produced by proteolytic processing of the pre-core protein. In some rare strains of the virus known as Hepatitis B virus precore mutants
column8: no HBeAg is present.

column2: pre-S1
column3: pre-S2
column4: and S. Because of the multiple start codons

column6: pre-S2
column7: and S )
column8: middle (pre-S2

column10: and small (S)  are produced. The function of the protein coded for by gene X is not fully understood but it is associated with the development of liver cancer. It stimulates genes that promote cell growth and inactivates growth regulating molecules.

column1: The life cycle of hepatitis B virus is complex. Hepatitis B is one of a few known pararetroviruses: non-retroviruses that still use reverse transcription in their replication process. The virus gains entry into the cell by binding to NTCP  on the surface and being endocytosed. Because the virus multiplies via RNA made by a host enzyme
column2: the viral genomic DNA has to be transferred to the cell nucleus by host proteins called chaperones. The partially double-stranded viral DNA is then made fully double stranded by a viral polymerase and transformed into covalently closed circular DNA (cccDNA). This cccDNA serves as a template for transcription of four viral mRNAs by host RNA polymerase. The largest mRNA
column3: (which is longer than the viral genome)
column4: is used to make the new copies of the genome and to make the capsid core protein and the viral DNA polymerase. These four viral transcripts undergo additional processing and go on to form progeny virions that are released from the cell or returned to the nucleus and re-cycled to produce even more copies. The long mRNA is then transported back to the cytoplasm where the virion P protein (the DNA polymerase) synthesizes DNA via its reverse transcriptase activity.

Two further types have since been described (G and H). Most genotypes are now divided into subgenotypes with distinct properties.

column1: Hepatitis B virus primarily interferes with the functions of the liver by replicating in hepatocytes. A functional receptor is NTCP. There is evidence that the receptor in the closely related duck hepatitis B virus is carboxypeptidase D. The virions bind to the host cell via the preS domain of the viral surface antigen and are subsequently internalized by endocytosis. HBV-preS-specific receptors are expressed primarily on hepatocytes; however
column2: viral DNA and proteins have also been detected in extrahepatic sites
column3: suggesting that cellular receptors for HBV may also exist on extrahepatic cells.During HBV infection
column4: the host immune response causes both hepatocellular damage and viral clearance. Although the innate immune response does not play a significant role in these processes

column6: in particular virus-specific cytotoxic T lymphocytes(CTLs)
column7: contributes to most of the liver injury associated with HBV infection. CTLs eliminate HBV infection by killing infected cells and producing antiviral cytokines
column8: which are then used to purge HBV from viable hepatocytes. Although liver damage is initiated and mediated by the CTLs
column9: antigen-nonspecific inflammatory cells can worsen CTL-induced immunopathology

column1: Vaccines for the prevention of hepatitis B have been routinely recommended for babies since 1991 in the United States. The first dose is generally recommended within a day of birth.Most vaccines are given in three doses over a course of months. A protective response to the vaccine is defined as an anti-HBs antibody concentration of  at least 10 mIU/ml in the recipient's serum. The vaccine is more effective in children and 95 percent of those vaccinated have protective levels of antibody. This drops to around 90% at 40 years of age  and to around 75 percent in those over 60 years. The protection afforded by vaccination is long lasting even after antibody levels fall below 10 mIU/ml. For newborns of HBsAg-positive mothers: hepatitis B vaccine alone
column2: hepatitis B immunoglobulin alone
column3: or the combination of vaccine plus hepatitis B immunoglobulin
column4: all prevent hepatitis B occurrence. Furthermore
column5: the combination of vaccine plus hepatitis B immunoglobulin is superior to vaccine alone. This combination prevents HBV transmission around the time of birth in 86% to 99% of cases.Tenofovir given in the second or third trimester can reduce the risk of mother to child transmission by 77% when combined with hepatitis B immunoglobulin and the hepatitis B vaccine
column6: especially for pregnant women with high hepatitis B virus DNA levels. However
column7: there is no sufficient evidence that the administration of hepatitis B immunoglobulin alone during pregnancy
column8: might reduce transmission rates to the newborn infant.  No randomized control trial has been conducted to assess the effects of hepatitis B vaccine during pregnancy for preventing infant infection.All those with a risk of exposure to body fluids such as blood should be vaccinated
column9: if not already. Testing to verify effective immunization is recommended and further doses of vaccine are given to those who are not sufficiently immunized.In 10- to 22-year follow-up studies there were no cases of hepatitis B among those with a normal immune system who were vaccinated. Only rare chronic infections have been documented. Vaccination is particularly recommended for high risk groups including: health workers
column10: people with chronic renal failure
column11: and men who have sex with men.Both types of the hepatitis B vaccine
column12: the plasma-derived vaccine (PDV) and recombinant vaccine (RV) are of similar effectiveness in preventing the infection in both healthcare workers and chronic renal failure groups. With one difference noticed among health worker group
column13: that the RV intramuscular route is significantly more effective compared with RV intradermal route of administration.

column4: a marker of liver damage
column5: and HBV DNA levels are candidates for therapy. Treatment lasts from six months to a year

column7: however
column8: is more variable and usually longer than one year.Although none of the available medications can clear the infection

column18: which requires injections daily or thrice weekly

column2: this drops to 30% for younger children

column2: leukemia is subdivided into a variety of large groups. The first division is between its acute and chronic forms:

column1: Acute leukemia is characterized by a rapid increase in the number of immature blood cells. column2: which then spill over into the bloodstream and spread to other organs of the body. Acute forms of leukemia are the most common forms of leukemia in children.

column3: white blood cells. Typically taking months or years to progress
column4: the cells are produced at a much higher rate than normal
column5: resulting in many abnormal white blood cells. Whereas acute leukemia must be treated immediately
column6: chronic forms are sometimes monitored for some time before treatment to ensure maximum effectiveness of therapy. Chronic leukemia mostly occurs in older people
column7: but can occur in any age group.Additionally

column1: Gout affects around 1–2% of the Western population at some point in their lifetimes and is becoming more common. Some 5.8 million people were affected in 2013. Rates of gout approximately doubled between 1990 and 2010. This rise is believed to be due to increasing life expectancy

column3: such as metabolic syndrome and high blood pressure. Factors that influence rates of gout

column5: race
column6: and the season of the year. In men over 30 and women over 50
column7: rates are 2%.In the United States

column9: but the disease is rare in aboriginal Australians
column10: despite a higher mean uric acid serum concentration in the latter group. It has become common in China
column11: Polynesia
column12: and urban sub-Saharan Africa. Some studies found that attacks of gout occur more frequently in the spring. This has been attributed to seasonal changes in diet
column13: alcohol consumption
column14: physical activity
column15: and temperature.

column6: 600 BC in a description of arthritis of the big toe. Greek physician Hippocrates around 400 BC commented on it in his Aphorisms

column5: or women except those in whom the menses have become suppressed... some have obtained lifelong security by refraining from wine

column2: generally
column3: either old men or men who have so worn themselves out in youth as to have brought on a premature old age—of such dissolute habits none being more common than the premature and excessive indulgence in venery and the like exhausting passions. The victim goes to bed and sleeps in good health. About two o'clock in the morning he is awakened by a severe pain in the great toe; more rarely in the heel

column1: Hepatitis C;"Hepatitis C is an infectious disease caused by the hepatitis C virus (HCV) that primarily affects the liver. During the initial infection people often have mild or no symptoms. Occasionally a fever
column2: dark urine
column3: abdominal pain
column4: and yellow tinged skin occurs. The virus persists in the liver in about 75% to 85% of those initially infected. Early on chronic infection typically has no symptoms. Over many years however
column5: it often leads to liver disease and occasionally cirrhosis. In some cases
column6: those with cirrhosis will develop serious complications such as liver failure
column7: liver cancer
column8: or dilated blood vessels in the esophagus and stomach.HCV is spread primarily by blood-to-blood contact associated with intravenous drug use
column9: poorly sterilized medical equipment
column10: needlestick injuries in healthcare
column11: and transfusions. Using blood screening
column12: the risk from a transfusion is less than one per two million. It may also be spread from an infected mother to her baby during birth. It is not spread by superficial contact. It is one of five known hepatitis viruses: A
column13: B
column14: C
column15: D
column16: and E. Diagnosis is by blood testing to look for either antibodies to the virus or its RNA. Testing is recommended in all people who are at risk.There is no vaccine against hepatitis C. Prevention includes harm reduction efforts among people who use intravenous drugs and testing donated blood. Chronic infection can be cured about 95% of the time with antiviral medications such as sofosbuvir or simeprevir. Peginterferon and ribavirin were earlier generation treatments that had a cure rate of less than 50% and greater side effects. Getting access to the newer treatments however can be expensive. Those who develop cirrhosis or liver cancer may require a liver transplant. Hepatitis C is the leading reason for liver transplantation
column17: though the virus usually recurs after transplantation.An estimated 143 million people (2%) worldwide are infected with hepatitis C as of 2015. In 2013 about 11 million new cases occurred. It occurs most commonly in Africa and Central and East Asia. About 167
column18: 000 deaths due to liver cancer and 326
column19: 000 deaths due to cirrhosis occurred in 2015 due to hepatitis C. The existence of hepatitis C – originally identifiable only as a type of non-A non-B hepatitis – was suggested in the 1970s and proven in 1989. Hepatitis C infects only humans and chimpanzees.

column1: Acute symptoms develop in some 20-30% of those infected. When this occurs
column2: it is generally 4–12 weeks following infection (but it may take from 2 weeks to 6 months for acute symptoms to appear).Symptoms are generally mild and vague
column3: and may include fatigue
column4: nausea and vomiting
column5: fever
column6: muscle or joint pains
column7: abdominal pain
column8: decreased appetite and weight loss
column9: jaundice (occurs in ~25% of those infected)
column10: dark urine
column11: and clay-coloured stools. There is no evidence that acute hepatitis C can alone cause acute liver failure
column12: though liver injury and elevated liver enzymes may occur. Symptoms and laboratory findings suggestive of liver disease should prompt further tests and can thus help establish a diagnosis of hepatitis C infection early on.Following the acute phase
column13: the infection may resolve spontaneously in 10–50% of affected people; this occurs more frequently in young people
column14: and females.

column1: About 80% of those exposed to the virus develop a chronic infection. This is defined as the presence of detectable viral replication for at least six months. Most experience minimal or no symptoms during the initial few decades of the infection. Chronic hepatitis C can be associated with fatigue and mild cognitive problems. Chronic infection after several years may cause cirrhosis or liver cancer. The liver enzymes are normal in 7–53%. Late relapses after apparent cure have been reported
column2: but these can be difficult to distinguish from reinfection.Fatty changes to the liver occur in about half of those infected and are usually present before cirrhosis develops. Usually (80% of the time) this change affects less than a third of the liver. Worldwide hepatitis C is the cause of 27% of cirrhosis cases and 25% of hepatocellular carcinoma. About 10–30% of those infected develop cirrhosis over 30 years. Cirrhosis is more common in those also infected with hepatitis B
column3: schistosoma
column4: or HIV
column5: in alcoholics and in those of male gender. In those with hepatitis C
column6: excess alcohol increases the risk of developing cirrhosis 100-fold. Those who develop cirrhosis have a 20-fold greater risk of hepatocellular carcinoma. This transformation occurs at a rate of 1–3% per year. Being infected with hepatitis B in addition to hepatitis C increases this risk further.Liver cirrhosis may lead to portal hypertension
column7: ascites (accumulation of fluid in the abdomen)
column8: easy bruising or bleeding
column9: varices (enlarged veins
column10: especially in the stomach and esophagus)
column11: jaundice
column12: and a syndrome of cognitive impairment known as hepatic encephalopathy. Ascites occurs at some stage in more than half of those who have a chronic infection.

column2: lichen planus
column3: a low platelet count

column8: diabetic nephropathy

Possible associations include Hyde's prurigo nodularis and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.  Cardiomyopathy with associated abnormal heart rhythms has also been reported. A variety of central nervous system disorders has been reported. Chronic infection seems to be associated with an increased risk of pancreatic cancer. People may experience other issues in the mouth such as dryness
column11: salivary duct stones

column1: Persons who have been infected with hepatitis C may appear to clear the virus but remain infected. The virus is not detectable with conventional testing but can be found with ultra-sensitive tests. The original method of detection was by demonstrating the viral genome within liver biopsies
column2: but newer methods include an antibody test for the virus' core protein and the detection of the viral genome after first concentrating the viral particles by ultracentrifugation. A form of infection with persistently moderately elevated serum liver enzymes but without antibodies to hepatitis C has also been reported. This form is known as cryptogenic occult infection.

column1: Several clinical pictures have been associated with this type of infection. It may be found in people with anti-hepatitis-C antibodies but with normal serum levels of liver enzymes; in antibody-negative people with ongoing elevated liver enzymes of unknown cause; in healthy populations without evidence of liver disease; and in groups at risk for HCV infection including those on hemodialysis or family members of people with occult HCV. The clinical relevance of this form of infection is under investigation. The consequences of occult infection appear to be less severe than with chronic infection but can vary from minimal to hepatocellular carcinoma.The rate of occult infection in those apparently cured is controversial but appears to be low. 40% of those with hepatitis but with both negative hepatitis C serology and the absence of detectable viral genome in the serum have hepatitis C virus in the liver on biopsy. How commonly this occurs in children is unknown.
The hepatitis C virus (HCV) is a small
column2: enveloped
column3: single-stranded
column4: positive-sense RNA virus. It is a member of the genus Hepacivirus in the family Flaviviridae. There are seven major genotypes of HCV
column5: which are known as genotypes one to seven. The genotypes are divided into several subtypes with the number of subtypes depending on the genotype. In the United States
column6: about 70% of cases are caused by genotype 1
column7: 20% by genotype 2 and about 1% by each of the other genotypes. Genotype 1 is also the most common in South America and Europe.The half life of the virus particles in the serum is around 3 hours and may be as short as 45 minutes. In an infected person
column8: about 1012 virus particles are produced each day. In addition to replicating in the liver the virus can multiply in lymphocytes.

column1: The primary route of transmission in the developed world is intravenous drug use (IDU)
column2: while in the developing world the main methods are blood transfusions and unsafe medical procedures. The cause of transmission remains unknown in 20% of cases; however
column3: many of these are believed to be accounted for by IDU.

column1: Intravenous drug use (IDU) is a major risk factor for hepatitis C in many parts of the world. Of 77 countries reviewed
column2: 25 (including the United States) were found to have prevalences of hepatitis C in the intravenous drug user population of between 60% and 80%.  Twelve countries had rates greater than 80%. It is believed that ten million intravenous drug users are infected with hepatitis C; China (1.6 million)
column3: the United States (1.5 million)
column4: and Russia (1.3 million) have the highest absolute totals. Occurrence of hepatitis C among prison inmates in the United States is 10 to 20 times that of the occurrence observed in the general population; this has been attributed to high-risk behavior in prisons such as IDU and tattooing with nonsterile equipment. Shared intranasal drug use may also be a risk factor.

column2: transfusion of blood products
column3: or organ transplants without HCV screening carry significant risks of infection. The United States instituted universal screening in 1992 and Canada instituted universal screening in 1990. This decreased the risk from one in 200 units to between one in 10
column4: 000 to one in 10
column6: 000 per unit of blood. This low risk remains as there is a period of about 11–70 days between the potential blood donor's acquiring hepatitis C and the blood's testing positive depending on the method. Some countries do not screen for hepatitis C due to the cost.Those who have experienced a needle stick injury from someone who was HCV positive have about a 1.8% chance of subsequently contracting the disease themselves. The risk is greater if the needle in question is hollow and the puncture wound is deep. There is a risk from mucosal exposures to blood
column7: but this risk is low
column8: and there is no risk if blood exposure occurs on intact skin.Hospital equipment has also been documented as a method of transmission of hepatitis C
column9: including reuse of needles and syringes; multiple-use medication vials; infusion bags; and improperly sterilized surgical equipment
column10: among others. Limitations in the implementation and enforcement of stringent standard precautions in public and private medical and dental facilities are known to be the primary cause of the spread of HCV in Egypt
column11: the country with highest rate of infection in the world.

column1: Sexual transmission of hepatitis C is uncommon. Studies examining the risk of HCV transmission between heterosexual partners
column2: when one is infected and the other is not

column6: including HIV or genital ulceration

column1: Tattooing is associated with two to threefold increased risk of hepatitis C. This can be due to either improperly sterilized equipment or contamination of the dyes being used. Tattoos or piercings performed either before the mid-1980s
column2: ""underground
column3: or nonprofessionally are of particular concern

It is estimated that nearly half of prison inmates share unsterilized tattooing equipment. It is rare for tattoos in a licensed facility to be directly associated with HCV infection.

column3: and manicuring or pedicuring equipment can be contaminated with blood. Sharing such items can potentially lead to exposure to HCV. Appropriate caution should be taken regarding any medical condition that results in bleeding

column1: There are a number of diagnostic tests for hepatitis C
column2: including HCV antibody enzyme immunoassay or ELISA
column3: recombinant immunoblot assay
column4: and quantitative HCV RNA polymerase chain reaction (PCR). HCV RNA can be detected by PCR typically one to two weeks after infection
column5: while antibodies can take substantially longer to form and thus be detected.Chronic hepatitis C is defined as infection with the hepatitis C virus persisting for more than six months based on the presence of its RNA. Chronic infections are typically asymptomatic during the first few decades
column6: and thus are most commonly discovered following the investigation of elevated liver enzyme levels or during a routine screening of high-risk individuals. Testing is not able to distinguish between acute and chronic infections. Diagnosis in the infant is difficult as maternal antibodies may persist for up to 18 months.

column1: Hepatitis C testing typically begins with blood testing to detect the presence of antibodies to the HCV
column2: using an enzyme immunoassay. If this test is positive
column3: a confirmatory test is then performed to verify the immunoassay and to determine the viral load. A recombinant immunoblot assay is used to verify the immunoassay and the viral load is determined by an HCV RNA polymerase chain reaction. If there is no RNA and the immunoblot is positive
column4: it means that the person tested had a previous infection but cleared it either with treatment or spontaneously; if the immunoblot is negative
column5: it means that the immunoassay was wrong. It takes about 6–8 weeks following infection before the immunoassay will test positive. A number of tests are available as point of care testing which means that results are available within 30 minutes.Liver enzymes are variable during the initial part of the infection and on average begin to rise at seven weeks after infection. The elevation of liver enzymes does not closely follow disease severity.There are reports of negative plasma PCR for the viral genome with positive PCR for the viral genome within peripheral blood monocytes of liver cells. This condition has been termed occult HCV infection and it was first recognized in 2004.

column1: It is believed that only 5–50% of those infected in the United States and Canada are aware of their status. Testing is recommended for those at high risk

column2: no approved vaccine protects against contracting hepatitis C. A combination of harm reduction strategies
column3: such as the provision of new needles and syringes and treatment of substance use
column4: decreases the risk of hepatitis C in intravenous drug users by about 75%. The screening of blood donors is important at a national level

column1: Those with chronic hepatitis C are advised to avoid alcohol and medications toxic to the liver. They should also be vaccinated against hepatitis A and hepatitis B due to the increased risk if also infected. Use of acetaminophen is generally considered safe at reduced doses. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are not recommended in those with advanced liver disease due to an increased risk of bleeding. Ultrasound surveillance for hepatocellular carcinoma is recommended in those with accompanying cirrhosis. Coffee consumption has been associated with a slower rate of liver scarring in those infected with HCV.

Approximately 90% of chronic cases clear with treatment. Treatment with antiviral medication is recommended in all people with proven chronic hepatitis C who are not at high risk of dying from other causes. People with the highest complication risk should be treated first

A 2013 review found unclear evidence regarding if antiviral medication was useful if the graft became reinfetcted.

The evidence for treatment in genotype 6 disease is sparse and what evidence there is supports 48 weeks of treatment at the same doses used for genotype 1 disease.

column1: Many low-grade lymphomas remain indolent for many years. Treatment of the nonsymptomatic patient is often avoided. In these forms of lymphoma
column2: such as follicular lymphoma
column3: watchful waiting is often the initial course of action. This is carried out because the harms and risks of treatment outweigh the benefits. If a low-grade lymphoma is becoming symptomatic
column4: radiotherapy or chemotherapy are the treatments of choice; although they do not cure the lymphoma

column7: but the disease is incurable. Some centers advocate the use of single agent rituximab in the treatment of follicular lymphoma rather than the wait and watch approach. Watchful waiting is not a good strategy for all patients
column8: as it leads to significant distress and anxiety in some patients. It has been equated with watch and worry.

column2: more aggressive
column3: forms of lymphoma can result in a cure in the majority of cases

column5: including the CHOP or R-CHOP regimen. A number of people are cured with first-line chemotherapy. Most relapses occur within the first two years
column6: and the relapse risk drops significantly thereafter. For people who relapse

column1: Hodgkin lymphoma typically is treated with radiotherapy alone

column4: which is commonly used in the United States. Other regimens used in the management of Hodgkin lymphoma include BEACOPP and Stanford V. Considerable controversy exists regarding the use of ABVD or BEACOPP. Briefly
column5: both regimens are effective

column1: The two types of lymphoma research are clinical or translational research and basic research. Clinical/translational research focuses on studying the disease in a defined and generally immediately patient-applicable way
column2: such as testing a new drug in patients.  Studies may focus on effective means of treatment
column3: better ways of treating the disease

column6: such as seeing whether a suspected carcinogen can cause healthy cells to turn into lymphoma cells in the laboratory or how the DNA changes inside lymphoma cells as the disease progresses.  The results from basic research studies are generally less immediately useful to patients with the disease

column1: The term ""σήψις"" (sepsis) was introduced by Hippocrates in the fourth century BC

column3: Avicenna used the term ""blood rot"" for diseases linked to severe purulent process. Though severe systemic toxicity had already been observed

column2: also spelled ""septicaemia""
column3: and ""blood poisoning"" referred to the microorganisms or their toxins in the blood and are no longer commonly used. The modern term for this is dependent on the microorganism that is present: bacteremia if bacteria are present in the blood at abnormal levels and are the causative issue
column4: viremia for viruses
column5: and fungemia for a fungus.By the end of the 19th century
column6: it was widely believed that microbes produced substances that could injure the mammalian host and that soluble toxins released during infection caused the fever and shock that were commonplace during severe infections. Pfeiffer coined the term endotoxin at the beginning of the 20th century to denote the pyrogenic principle associated with Vibrio cholerae. It was soon realised that endotoxins were expressed by most and perhaps all gram-negative bacteria. The lipopolysaccharide character of enteric endotoxins was elucidated in 1944 by Shear. The molecular character of this material was determined by Luderitz et al. in 1973.It was discovered in 1965 that a strain of C3H/HeJ mice were immune to the endotoxin-induced shock. The genetic locus for this effect was dubbed Lps. These mice were also found to be hypersusceptible to infection by gram-negative bacteria. These observations were finally linked in 1998 by the discovery of the toll-like receptor gene 4 (TLR 4). Genetic mapping work
column7: performed over a period of five years
column8: showed that TLR4 was the sole candidate locus within the Lps critical region; this strongly implied that a mutation within TLR4 must account for the lipopolysaccharide resistance phenotype. The defect in the TLR4 gene that led to the endotoxin resistant phenotype was discovered to be due to a mutation in the cytoplasm.Controversy occurred in the scientific community over the use of mouse models in research into sepsis in 2013
column9: when scientists published a review of the mouse immune system compared to the human immune system
column10: and showed that on a systems level
column11: the two worked very differently; the authors noted that as of the date of their article over 150 clinical trials of sepsis had been conducted in humans
column12: almost all of them supported by promising data in mice
column13: and that all of them had failed. The authors called for abandoning the use of mouse models in sepsis research; others rejected that but called for more caution in interpreting the results of mouse studies
